raw_text: Doctor:Doctor Good morning, what brings you to the Outpatient department today?
Patient:Patient Good morning doctor, I have some discomfort in my neck and lower back, and I'm not able to maintain an erect posture.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, okay. Can you tell me more about the discomfort?
Patient:Patient Yes, I tend to fall on either side when I stand up from a sitting position, and my head is always turned to the right and upwards.
Doctor:Doctor I see. Are you experiencing any pain in your neck?
Patient:Patient Yes, I have pain and discomfort in my neck.
Doctor:Doctor Okay. And what about your back?

Patient:Patient There is a sideways bending in my lumbar region. To counter the abnormal positioning of my back and neck, I have to keep my limbs in a specific position to allow my body weight to be supported.
Doctor:Doctor I understand. Does this restriction of body movements affect your daily life?
Patient:Patient Yes, I need assistance in standing and walking, and my parents have to help me with my daily chores, including all activities of self-care.
Doctor:Doctor I see. How long have you been experiencing these difficulties?
Patient:Patient I've been experiencing these difficulties for the past four months since I was introduced to olanzapine tablets for the control of my exacerbated mental illness.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And you've been diagnosed with bipolar affective disorder, correct?
Patient:Patient Yes, I was diagnosed with bipolar affective disorder seven years ago.
Doctor:Doctor And you've been taking olanzapine for your mental illness for seven years, correct?
Patient:Patient Yes, I have. My first episode of the affective disorder was mania when I was eleven, and I've been taking olanzapine tablets in 2.5-10 mg doses per day at different times.
Doctor:Doctor I see. So, you developed pain and discomfort in your neck within the second week of being put on olanzapine at a dose of 5 mg per day, correct?
Patient:Patient Yes, that's correct. The sustained and abnormal contraction of my neck muscles pulls my head to the right in an upward direction.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And these features have persisted for the first three years of your illness with a varying intensity, distress, and dysfunction, correct?
Patient:Patient Yes, that's correct. The intensity, distress, and dysfunction tend to correlate with the dose of olanzapine.

Doctor:Doctor I see. And apart from a brief period of around three weeks when you were given trihexyphenidyl 4 mg per day for rigidity in your upper limbs, you were not prescribed any other psychotropic medication, correct?
Patient:Patient Yes, that's correct. The rigidity showed good response to trihexyphenidyl 4 mg per day.
Doctor:Doctor Okay. I'm going to order some tests for you, and I'll be able to give you a proper diagnosis after that.
Doctor:Doctor I'll also instruct you on follow-up requirements.
Doctor:Doctor Hi, how are you feeling today?
Patient:Patient Hi doctor, I have this dump pain on my right back and a swelling right there for several weeks.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I see. Can you describe the pain a little more?
Patient:Patient It's like a dull ache and it hurts more when I move.
Doctor:Doctor Okay. I understand. And you said you're in good state and very active?
Doctor:Doctor That's good to hear. Have you had any health problems in the past?
Patient:Patient Well, I had a thoracic trauma at work one year ago.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And what was the diagnosis for that?
Patient:Patient I was diagnosed with a simple fracture of the 9th right rib.
Doctor:Doctor Okay. After the X-ray, we decided to perform a CT-scan of the thorax, and it revealed a tumor of the thoracic wall in the right hemithorax.
Doctor:Doctor Yes, it measured 8 × 4 cm and had a heterogeneous density inside of it. The tumor had involved and destructed the 9th rib and was lying even in two adjacent intercostal spaces.

Doctor:Doctor Yes, it is. But the good news is that it didn't involve the lung and muscular layers. On lung window of the CT-scan, we saw micronodular infiltrations of both lungs with diameters up to 5 mm and only one nodule in lower lobe of the right lung with diameter almost 1 cm.

Doctor:Doctor The mediastinum was without enlarged lymph nodes and no other lesion was seen in adjacent organs. The conclusion of the radiologist was that probably this was the case of a malignant tumor of the thoracic wall with secondary lesions in both lungs.
Patient:Patient So what do we do now?
Doctor:Doctor We need to perform a biopsy of the tumor to confirm the diagnosis.

Doctor:Doctor Because there was not a correlation between the clinical picture of the patient and the conclusion of the radiology, we decided to perform frozen biopsy of the lesions of the right lung and an excision biopsy of the tumor of the thoracic wall.
Patient:Patient And what happened after that?

Doctor:Doctor Through a small posterior thoracotomy at 7th intercostal space, we sampled five nodular lesions from the right lung and a sample from the tumor. None of these samples resulted positive for malignant cells.
Doctor:Doctor Yes, it is. In such conditions, we considered it more realistic to perform an oncologic resection of the tumor of the thoracic wall.
Doctor:Doctor We resected three ribs where the 8th and 9th ribs were involved in the tumor.
Doctor:Doctor You need to follow up with us regularly to make sure everything is going well.
Patient:Patient Of course, doctor. Thank you.
Doctor:Doctor Hello, what brings you to the hospital today?
Patient:Patient Hi, I have been experiencing pain and restricted range of motion in my left hip joint for two months now. I also have a gait disturbance.
Doctor:Doctor I see. Can you tell me more about your chief complaint?
Patient:Patient Sure. I have been having severe pain in my left hip that gets worse when I try to flex or rotate it. And my gait is also affected because of the pain.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I understand. Can you tell me if you have any lifestyle habits or comorbidities that may have caused this?
Patient:Patient No, I don't think so.

Doctor:Doctor Alright. Let me take a look at your physical examination results.
[Doctor examines patient's physical examination results]

Doctor:Doctor Yes, it looks like you have a severe gait disturbance secondary to hip pain, which is aggravated by hip joint flexion or rotation. And it also says here that there is no lifestyle habits or comorbidities thought to cause femoral head AVN.

Doctor:Doctor An anteroposterior view of your left hip revealed sclerosis and collapse of the femoral head and dysplasia of the hip. And the magnetic resonance imaging scan showed an increased amount of joint fluid and bone marrow edema in your left hip.
Doctor:Doctor And we also detected femoral head necrosis on the contralateral side, but you didn't complain of any pain.
Doctor:Doctor So, based on the results, we diagnosed you with idiopathic osteonecrosis of the femoral head. And you underwent THA for treatment.
Doctor:Doctor And it says here that you were discharged in good condition three weeks after the surgery without specific complications, and you followed up via regular outpatient visits.

Doctor:Doctor But then, you complained of pain and limited ROM in the contralateral hip joint and gait disturbance one year after the initial surgery. And your symptoms continued for two months and increased over the following three weeks.

Doctor:Doctor And then, you underwent a second THA one year after the first THA of the left hip. And you were discharged in good condition after the surgery without specific complications, and followed up via regular outpatient visits.

Doctor:Doctor At the time of the second surgery, you were 7 kg heavier than you were at the time of the first procedure and developed a moderate moon face, signs that were initially overlooked as weight gain.

Doctor:Doctor And then, you complained of intensifying feelings of helplessness and central obesity and muscle mass reduction in both the upper and lower limbs, which were aggravated over a three-month period of outpatient follow-up after the second surgery.

Doctor:Doctor But these signs were not significant enough to warrant further investigation. And one year after the second surgery, you were referred to the Department of Cardiology in our hospital due to a progressive worsening of central.
Doctor:Doctor Good morning, Mr. [Patient's Name]. I'm Dr. [Doctor's Name]. What brings you in today?
Patient:Patient Good morning, doctor. I have a pain in my left arm after a fall.
Doctor:Doctor I see. Can you tell me more about the fall and the pain you're experiencing?
Patient:Patient I fell and hit my left arm about three months ago. The pain has been getting worse and I can't move my arm as well as I used to.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I understand. I see from your medical history that you had a surgery on your left elbow for posttraumatic arthritis when you were 18. Is that correct?
Doctor:Doctor Okay. I'd like to do a physical examination to see what's going on. Can you describe the pain you're feeling?
Patient:Patient It's a sharp pain in my left proximal forearm.
Doctor:Doctor Alright. I'll examine your arm now. Can you move your arm for me?
Patient:Patient No, I can't. My elbow is fused at 90 degrees and I can only do 40 degrees of pronation and 60 degrees of supination.
Doctor:Doctor I see. Your motor and sensory exam is normal at the hand, right?

Doctor:Doctor Alright. We have taken some radiographs of your forearm and elbow. They showed a minimally displaced proximal ulnar shaft fracture and an elbow arthrodesis at 90 degrees with retained hardware.

Doctor:Doctor After your fall, you developed a hypertrophic nonunion of your ulnar shaft fracture, and we treated it with a cast for three months. But your motion through the nonunion site worsened, and you were unhappy with the functional limitations of your elbow arthrodesis.

Doctor:Doctor We discussed the surgical options for the ulna nonunion with you at your clinic visit three months after the fall, and we decided to proceed with conservative treatment for an additional three months.

Doctor:Doctor Due to your prior surgery and history of trauma, as well as the risk of infection, we chose to avoid multiple surgeries and combine the repair of the nonunion and the conversion of the elbow arthrodesis to arthroplasty into one procedure. The stem of the ulnar component would act as an intramedullary device.

Doctor:Doctor During the procedure, you were placed in a supine position and a posterior incision was performed over your elbow. We had to elevate a prior muscle flap that was used for soft tissue coverage at your index procedure. The ulnar nerve was encased in scar tissue and required a meticulous neuroplasty.
Doctor:Doctor We performed a triceps splitting approach to your elbow joint and multiple buried pins were inserted.
Doctor:Doctor Is there anything you don't understand or have any questions about the procedure?
Patient:Patient No, I think you've explained everything clearly. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor:Doctor You're welcome. You'll need to come back for follow-up appointments to monitor your progress. If you have any concerns or questions, don't hesitate to ask.
Doctor:Doctor Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient:Patient Hi doctor, I'm not feeling great. I have been experiencing pain in my knees for over a year now.
Doctor:Doctor I see. You were referred to our clinic for recurrent attacks of pain in both knees, correct?
Doctor:Doctor Can you tell me more about the pain you have been experiencing?

Patient:Patient Well, it started about a year ago with severe pain over the medial aspect of my left knee. It lasted for two weeks and it was so bad that I couldn't walk. The pain increased when I did any weight-bearing activities.
Doctor:Doctor I understand. Did you have any history of trauma before the onset of your knee pain?

Doctor:Doctor Okay, let me take a look. (Examines the patient's knee) Hmm, I can see that there is severe tenderness over the medial side of your knee with mild effusion and moderate limitation of range of motion. There is no erythema or increased warmth of the knee.
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what I've been experiencing.

Doctor:Doctor We have done an MRI of your left knee and it showed a moderate-sized focal area of marrow edema/contusion involving the medial femoral condyle in mid and anterior parts predominantly along the articular surface.
Patient:Patient What does that mean, doctor?

Doctor:Doctor It means that there is some injury to the bone in your knee. But don't worry, we have prescribed diclofenac sodium 50 mg twice daily for you and advised you to avoid prolonged weight-bearing activities.
Doctor:Doctor And it seems like the pain subsided and resolved over the next few weeks, is that correct?

Doctor:Doctor However, three months later, you developed spontaneous new onset of pain involving the lateral aspect of the same knee. And the MRI showed bone marrow edema involving the lateral femoral condyle with complete resolution of the bone marrow edema of the medial femoral condyle.
Doctor:Doctor We treated you conservatively with NSAIDs and physiotherapy and advised you to use a cane to minimize weight bearing on the diseased knee.
Doctor:Doctor And in April of this year, you developed gradual pain over the medial side of your right knee with no obvious swelling.
Doctor:Doctor And the MRI of your right knee showed a moderate-sized focal area of marrow edema involving the medial tibial plateau medially and anteriorly.
Doctor:Doctor We treated you in a similar fashion to the previous episode. And four months later, the pain got more severe, is that correct?

Doctor:Doctor And another MRI of your right knee showed extensive marrow edema involving the medial femoral condyle with complete recovery of the medial tibial plateau bone marrow edema noted in the previous MRI.

Doctor:Doctor Okay, I see. I will have to refer you to an orthopedic specialist for further evaluation and treatment. In the meantime, please continue to take your medications and avoid any weight-bearing activities that may worsen your condition.
Doctor:Doctor Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient:Patient Not so good, doctor. I'm here because I can't walk.
Doctor:Doctor I understand. Can you tell me a little bit about your history?
Patient:Patient Yes, I've had a long history of osteomalacia. I've been unable to walk for the last 4 years because of severe weakness and pain in my bones.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about the pain?
Patient:Patient Sure. I reported that for the last 2 years, I was so weak that I couldn't even turn over in bed. The pain was all over my body.
Doctor:Doctor I understand. Can you tell me when your condition started?
Patient:Patient It started when I was a baby. I didn't start walking until I was 2.5 years old. When I started school, I could walk but I couldn't run.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And did your family seek medical help for your condition?
Patient:Patient No, we were poor and couldn't afford it.
Doctor:Doctor I understand. Can you tell me about your marriage and pregnancy?

Patient:Patient I got married at a young age of 15 and got pregnant soon after that. During my pregnancy, I had difficulty walking and pain in my legs. I needed assistance to rise from a sitting position and was told I would need a cesarean section because I had a contracted pelvis. But I went into labor before I was able to have a cesarean section and delivered vaginally. I developed a fracture of the pubic rami during delivery.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, that sounds very difficult. And how did your condition worsen over the years?

Patient:Patient Over the following years, I had more difficulty walking and needed assistance climbing stairs. I went to several orthopedic surgeons and was diagnosed with osteomalacia. I was given calcium and vitamin D, but there was no improvement. I eventually became bedridden.
Doctor:Doctor I see. Were you given any other treatments?
Patient:Patient Yes, I was also given calcitriol in small doses for short periods of time, 0.25 mg daily. But I stopped all treatments when I didn't see any improvement in my condition.
Doctor:Doctor I understand. Were you seen by a neurologist?
Patient:Patient Yes, I was. They found that I had a normal nerve conduction study and was told there was no evidence of neurological disease.
Doctor:Doctor That's good to hear. Do you have a family history of this condition?
Patient:Patient No, there's no history of this condition in my parents, siblings, or other relatives.
Doctor:Doctor I see. Can you tell me about your physical examination when you first presented to the clinic?
Patient:Patient Sure. I was 144 cm tall and weighed 49 kg. I was much shorter than the rest of my family.

Doctor:Doctor I understand. Based on your history and examination, it sounds like you have osteomalacia. I'll order some tests to confirm the diagnosis. In the meantime, please be sure to follow up with me for further instructions.
Doctor:Doctor Hi there, I am Dr. Smith. How can I help you today?
Patient:Patient Hi, my daughter was admitted to the hospital a few days ago.
Doctor:Doctor Okay, let me take a look at her report first. So, she's a 24-day-old female baby, right?
Doctor:Doctor And she presented with dyspnea and fever, is that right?
Patient:Patient Yes, she was having trouble breathing and had a high fever.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I see. Let me ask you a few questions related to her symptoms. Did she have any cough or chest pain?
Patient:Patient No, she didn't have any cough or chest pain.
Doctor:Doctor Okay. And did you notice any wheezing or crackles when she was breathing?
Patient:Patient No, I didn't hear anything like that.
Doctor:Doctor Alright. The examination showed decreased air entry on the left side, right?
Doctor:Doctor And the chest radiograph showed what looked like a consolidation of that lung and air-filled bowel loops inside the chest.
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what the report said.
Doctor:Doctor And the ultrasound examination also identified intrathoracic ipsilateral kidney, correct?

Doctor:Doctor So, a computed tomography of her thorax was performed, which confirmed the left-sided diaphragmatic defect with large and small bowel and a normal looking, completely intrathoracic, ipsilateral left kidney and adrenal gland.
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what the report said.
Doctor:Doctor And the baby was delivered by spontaneous vaginal delivery with no antenatal diagnosis, right?
Doctor:Doctor And she had normal Apgar score and did not require any resuscitation.
Patient:Patient Yes, she was fine after birth.
Doctor:Doctor Good. The procedure was performed in left lateral decubitus position, right?
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what I heard.
Doctor:Doctor And a 5 mm camera port was inserted by open technique in anterior axillary and two 3 mm working ports were inserted under vision on either side of camera port.
Doctor:Doctor And the examination confirmed the CT findings, right?
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what the report said.

Doctor:Doctor And the herniated large and small bowel was pushed and reduced into the abdominal cavity through the diaphragmatic defect which then revealed a completely intrathoracic kidney encased in Gerota's fascia.
Doctor:Doctor And the kidney was then reduced into the abdominal cavity retroperitoneally by pushing it down through the diaphragmatic defect.
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what I heard.
Doctor:Doctor And a primary repair using interrupted nonabsorbable sutures was achieved without tension.
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what the report said.
Doctor:Doctor And initially the gas pressure during the reduction in hernia contents was kept at 6 mm Hg but was then reduced to 4 mm Hg during closure of the defect.
Doctor:Doctor And a chest drain was left in situ through the 5 mm port site at the end of procedure as there was violation of the pleura.
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what I heard.
Doctor:Doctor The baby had uneventful recovery and was extubated within 24 hours and chest drain was removed after 48 hours.
Patient:Patient Yes, she was doing much better after that.
Doctor:Doctor Good. And the renal ultrasound scan showed a correctly positioned kidney with good perfusion and no signs of obstruction.
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what the report said.
Doctor:Doctor And she was discharged on day 5 postoperatively and is being followed up as an outpatient.
Patient:Patient Yes, she's been doing well since then.

Doctor:Doctor That's great to hear. Her most recent renal ultrasound scan done 3 years postoperatively showed well and equally perfused kidneys with comparable renal volumes bilaterally without any evidence of hydronephrosis or hydroureter, or recurrence.
Patient:Patient Yes, she's been doing great. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor:Doctor You're welcome. If you have any concerns or questions, please feel free to ask.
Patient:Patient Okay, I will. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor:Doctor You're welcome. Have a good day.
Doctor:Doctor Good morning, what brings you here today?
Patient:Patient Good morning, doctor. I have been unable to walk on both my lower limbs for the past three months.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about this problem? When did it start and how did it progress?
Patient:Patient About three months ago, I started having pain in my right groin while walking. I was limping and swaying to either side. Then, I couldn't bear weight on my right lower limb.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And what happened after that?
Patient:Patient A week later, I had similar pain in my left groin and couldn't bear weight on either lower limb. I've been bedridden since then.
Doctor:Doctor Okay. Have you had any other symptoms besides the inability to walk?
Patient:Patient No, just the pain in my groins and the inability to walk.

Doctor:Doctor Alright. Based on your symptoms and our clinical findings, it seems that you have a coxa vara deformity of your bilateral hips with a possibility of a bilateral non-union of the pathological fracture of the femur neck.
Doctor:Doctor There was no evidence of any endocrine disturbance or altered pigmentation, or precocious puberty.

Doctor:Doctor Our imaging showed that you have suffered from polyostotic fibrous dysplasia with bilateral Shepherd's crook deformity of the proximal femur with bilateral non-union of the pathological fracture of the neck femur.
Doctor:Doctor The imaging of the other bones showed evidence of the fibrous dysplastic lesions in the shaft of your left tibia.

Doctor:Doctor The magnetic resonance scanning of your bilateral hip region showed features consistent with fibrous dysplasia of the proximal femur shaft along with a sub-capital fracture of the femur neck, without evidence of avascular necrosis of the femur head.

Doctor:Doctor All of your blood and serum biochemical tests, such as your hemoglobin, total and differential white cell counts, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, calcium, phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase levels, and all of your hormonal studies were within normal limits.

Doctor:Doctor Based on all of these findings, we have decided to do both correction of the deformity to realign the head, neck, and shaft, and to achieve valgus at the neck-shaft region and a horizontal configuration neck fracture, increasing the chances of union of the pathological fracture of the neck femur, in one stage, each side at a time.
Doctor:Doctor On the right side, we first did an oblique osteotomy from just distal to the greater trochanter.
Doctor:Doctor This procedure will help to correct your deformity and realign your bones to allow you to walk again.
Doctor:Doctor You will need to come back for follow-up appointments so that we can monitor your progress and make sure that everything is healing properly.
Doctor:Doctor Is there anything you would like to ask or discuss before we proceed with the next step?
Patient:Patient No, I think you've explained everything clearly. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor:Doctor You're welcome. I'll see you at your next appointment. Take care.
Doctor:Doctor Good morning, sir. How can I help you today?
Patient:Patient Good morning, doctor. I'm here because I have been concerned with having a cancer that would give me only a few days to live.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I see. Can you tell me a little more about your symptoms?
Patient:Patient I've been feeling tired and weak, and I've been losing weight.
Doctor:Doctor Okay. We'll start by taking a detailed history and documenting your symptoms.
Doctor:Doctor And we'll also perform some physical examinations to check for any signs of cancer.
Doctor:Doctor And we'll order some radiological and pathological investigations to rule out cancer.
Doctor:Doctor After we get the results, we'll create a management plan for you based on the findings.
Doctor:Doctor The results of the investigations came back and they were all negative for cancer.
Patient:Patient What do you mean? I'm sure I have cancer.
Doctor:Doctor I understand that you're concerned, but the tests came back negative.
Doctor:Doctor I understand that you're not satisfied with the results, so we've referred you to the Psychiatry Department to be evaluated.
Patient:Patient What do you mean by that?
Doctor:Doctor We want to see if there might be a nonorganic cause for your symptoms, either psychological or mental.

Doctor:Doctor The hospital administration has reported your case to the department of medical eligibility, addressing the issue of your continuous visits to the primary health care center with very variable symptoms, nonconclusive diagnosis, and an unconvinced patient.
Patient:Patient What does that mean for me?
Doctor:Doctor It means that your file has been temporarily limited to the psychiatry department, and we want you to visit the psychiatrist to be evaluated psychologically.
Patient:Patient I'm not happy about this, but I'll do it.
Doctor:Doctor The appointment with the psychiatrist has been booked, and a full psychological and social evaluation will be performed.
Doctor:Doctor The evaluation revealed that you fit the criteria of the illness anxiety disorder, in which you have a persistent belief of having a serious disease for at least six months.
Doctor:Doctor This persistent occupation with this belief is disabling and limiting you from having a normal life.
Doctor:Doctor Hi, how are you feeling today?
Doctor:Doctor Can you tell me what happened that brought you here today?

Patient:Patient Yes, I have a swelling on my scalp that started a year ago and has gradually gotten worse over the past six months. I had surgery to remove it, but the bleeding started at the beginning of the operation and the procedure was terminated.
Doctor:Doctor I see. Did you have any other symptoms besides the swelling?
Doctor:Doctor Okay. And did you have any imaging guidance during the surgery?
Patient:Patient No, I had the surgery under local anesthesia without any guidance.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And after the first surgery, did you have any other problems?

Patient:Patient Yes, five months later, the swelling increased and I saw another physician. They performed a cerebral magnetic resonance imaging and felt that it was a simple skin lesion that could be completely removed. But when I had the second surgery, I experienced severe bleeding.
Doctor:Doctor Okay. And that's why you were referred to our clinic, right?
Doctor:Doctor Alright. Can you tell me about your physical examination?

Patient:Patient Sure. The exam showed a painful mass lesion measuring 5 cm × 4 cm × 4 cm in the left parietal region at the vertex level. I didn't have any other complaints except for the esthetic problem.
Doctor:Doctor Okay. And what were the results of your neurological examination?

Doctor:Doctor Alright. After considering all the information, we performed a cerebral MR angiography and found a vascular mass lesion in the left parietal region that was supplied by the branches of the left external carotid artery. But the venous drainage could not be clearly identified.

Doctor:Doctor So, we performed a conventional cerebral angiography and detected an AVM in the left parietal region that was supplied via the branches of the left temporalis superficial artery, left meningeal media artery, and right temporalis superficialis artery.

Doctor:Doctor The lesion didn't have an intracranial component and didn't have direct drainage into the dural sinuses. So, we performed a surgical treatment under general anesthesia in the supine position with your head elevated at a 30° angle.

Doctor:Doctor The skin flap was removed with a horseshoe incision considering the vascularization of the scalp. The vascular lesion in the soft tissue was dissected, and the malformation was revealed. Initially, the supplying arteries of the lesion were closed, and later the lesion was completely removed along with its nidus.
Doctor:Doctor The bone underlying the lesion had become.
Doctor:Doctor So, you need to come back for a follow-up in a few weeks to make sure everything is healing properly. Do you have any questions or concerns?
Patient:Patient No, I don't think so. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor:Doctor No problem. If anything comes up, feel free to reach out to us. Take care.

Doctor:Doctor Good morning, Mr. [Patient's Name], I am Dr. [Doctor's Name]. I understand you were referred to our department for episodes of intermittent gross hematuria. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient:Patient Yes, I have been experiencing episodes of gross hematuria for a while now.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I see. And I understand you have a history of colorectal carcinoma that was treated with rectum and ileum segment resection, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy four years ago.
Doctor:Doctor After the radiotherapy, did you experience any other symptoms?
Patient:Patient Yes, I developed ureteric strictures on both sides and had to have ureteric stents placed.
Doctor:Doctor Okay, I see. And when you came in for admission, what did the urine specimen show?
Patient:Patient The urine specimen showed a few red blood cells and white blood cells, but the culture was sterile.
Doctor:Doctor I see. During the change of the ureteric stents, a retrograde pyelography and cystoscopy were performed, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And what did the results show?
Patient:Patient The results showed mild gross hematuria coming out of the right ureteric orifice, but there were no further pathological findings.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I see. After the stent change, did the hematuria clear up?
Patient:Patient At first, yes, but then one day later there was another episode of gross hematuria with blood clots in the bladder.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And a transurethral catheter was placed, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And a multiphase CT of the abdomen and pelvis was performed, but no source of bleeding was detected.
Doctor:Doctor And an ureteroscopy was performed on both ureteric sides with special emphasis on the right ureter, but nothing suspicious was found.
Doctor:Doctor And then there was another episode of gross hematuria with massive hemorrhage, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And an arteriography was performed, but once again no underlying reason for the bleeding was found.
Doctor:Doctor And two days later, there was another episode of gross hematuria with massive hemorrhage and the patient became hemodynamically unstable, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And the patient needed a blood transfusion of 6 units, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And the indication for nephrectomy of the suspicious right side was set and performed, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And during the operation, the ureteric stent was removed and the hematuria stopped, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And after the operation, there was a massive hemorrhage within the bladder catheter, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And an arteriography was performed and the region of the fistula was identified at the distal common iliac artery and a stent graft was deployed across the fistula, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And a postoperative angiogram showed complete closure of the fistula, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And after adequate blood transfusion and fluid replacement, the patient made a rapid and unremarkable recovery, correct?
Doctor:Doctor And twelve months later, the patient is still well and the stent graft remains patent, but the patient lost the right kidney, correct?
Doctor:Doctor Thank you for your cooperation. I will go over your medical history and test results and get back to you with a plan of action.
Doctor:Doctor Hello, can you tell me what happened to you?
Patient:Patient Hi, I suddenly felt abdominal pain and was taken to another hospital by ambulance.
Doctor:Doctor I see. Did they do any tests to find out what was causing the pain?
Patient:Patient Yes, they did a computed tomography (CT) scan.
Doctor:Doctor Okay, and what did the CT results show?
Patient:Patient The CT showed that I had a 5 cm diameter cystic tumor in my pancreatic tail with fluid collection around it.
Doctor:Doctor Hmm, I see. And the CT indicated that the acute abdominal pain was due to the hemoperitoneum caused by the rupture of the pancreatic tumor, right?
Patient:Patient Yes, that's what they said.

Doctor:Doctor I see you were admitted to our department due to a cystic tumor in your pancreas. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient:Patient Hmm, I started feeling some pain in my stomach a few weeks ago and I couldn't eat properly.
Doctor:Doctor I see. We did some tests and your routine chemistry and tumor marker levels were all within normal limits.

Doctor:Doctor That's great to hear. We also did a CT scan and it showed a slightly septated cystic tumor in your pancreas.

Doctor:Doctor There was no mural nodule, no calcification, and no eccentrically located mass within the cystic area. Based on these results, the benign mucinous cystic tumor of the pancreas was the most favorable preoperative diagnosis.
Doctor:Doctor We performed a laparoscopic distal pancreatectomy on you, which is a type of operation to remove the tumor.
Doctor:Doctor During the operation, we used a trocar placement and connected the robotic camera arm and other three instrument arms to their respective ports.
Doctor:Doctor The assistant surgeon was positioned on your left side for temporary use of laparoscopic instruments through Port 4.
Doctor:Doctor During the operation, we encountered some bleeding because the cystic tumor and the remaining splenic vessels were so closely adherent.
Doctor:Doctor To avoid the risk of cyst rupture, we thought it was necessary to do a concomitant segmental resection of splenic vessels for spleen preservation.
Doctor:Doctor The total operation took about 480 minutes and there was about 800 mL of blood loss, but we didn't need to give you a blood transfusion.
Doctor:Doctor The specimen was delivered through a small vertical incision after putting it into a plastic bag.
Doctor:Doctor You recovered without any complications and returned to an oral diet on the postoperative second day. After the drain was removed, you were discharged on the fifth day post-operation.
Doctor:Doctor The final pathologic examination revealed that the tumor was a benign mucinous cystic neoplasm without any characteristics of malignant potential.

Doctor:Doctor A color doppler ultrasound scan obtained 14 days after surgery showed no evidence of splenic infarction and well preserved blood flow within the spleen without definitive peripancreatic fluid collection.

Patient:Patient Yes, Neurologic examination revealed a 6th cranial nerve palsy on the right side and increased deep tendon reflexes in the four extremities.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And what about the MR imaging?
Patient:Patient On MR imaging, a giant aneurysm of the basilar artery was found to be compressing the brain stem.
Doctor:Doctor Okay, and what did the cerebral angiography show?
Patient:Patient The cerebral angiography showed a fusiform giant aneurysm, with an irregular contour, involving the basilar trunk.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And what was the situation with the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery?
Patient:Patient The left anterior inferior cerebellar artery originated just proximal to the basilar trunk aneurysm. In addition, another de novo small paraclinoid aneurysm was found on the left ICA.
Doctor:Doctor I understand. And what was the treatment plan?
Patient:Patient To relieve the brain stem compression, the doctor decided to obliterate the basilar trunk aneurysm in spite of the risk associated with this intervention.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And what was done before performing endovascular embolization of the aneurysm?

Patient:Patient In advance of performing endovascular embolization of the aneurysm, a high-flow bypass from the external carotid artery to the middle cerebral artery was performed using a saphenous vein graft.
Doctor:Doctor I understand. And why was the bypass performed?

Patient:Patient This was because occlusion of the basilar trunk would have endangered the blood supply to the posterior circulation, leaving the left ICA as the only vessel responsible for the perfusion of the entire brain after the basilar trunk occlusion, since I had already undergone occlusion of the right ICA.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And what did the bypass supply?
Patient:Patient The bypass supplied the right middle cerebral artery territory.
Doctor:Doctor I see. And what happened to the blood supply to the upper portion of the posterior circulation?
Patient:Patient An adequate blood supply to the upper portion of the posterior circulation was maintained via the left posterior communicating artery (PCoA).
Doctor:Doctor I understand. And what happened during surgery?
Patient:Patient During surgery, part of the occluded right ICA was sectioned.
Doctor:Doctor I see. Thank you for explaining to me. I will take a look at your file and get back to you with the follow-up plan.
Doctor:Doctor Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient:Patient Hi, doctor. I am feeling much better now.
Doctor:Doctor I am glad to hear that. Can you tell me about the chest and back pain that brought you here?
Patient:Patient I had been experiencing it for two weeks prior to my presentation.
Doctor:Doctor Did you take any medication for it?
Patient:Patient Yes, I took nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, but they were not effective.
Doctor:Doctor I see. During the physical examination, we found that your vital signs were stable. How were you feeling at that time?
Patient:Patient I was conscious and moving all my limbs.

Doctor:Doctor That's great. The CTA of the aorta revealed a large dissection flap from the origin of the left subclavian artery extending down to the level of renal arteries. It also showed enlargement of the false lumen at the proximal aorta with a large aneurysmal dilatation and a compression of the true lumen. Additionally, there was a large entry point seen 2 cm distal to the right subclavian artery.
Patient:Patient Oh my, that sounds serious.

Doctor:Doctor Yes, it was. However, we underwent thoracic endovascular repair (TEVAR) two days after your first day of admission. It was done through the right femoral approach, and a stent graft was used. The intimal entry tear was completely covered by the stent, and the false lumen was obliterated.
Patient:Patient I see. Did the procedure go well?

Doctor:Doctor Yes, it did. A postdeployment angiogram revealed successful proximal occlusion of the entry point with no perfusion of the false lumen and good flow through both carotid and left vertebral arteries as well as patent right and left subclavian arteries.
Patient:Patient That's good news. How long do I need to stay here in the intensive care unit?
Doctor:Doctor You were discharged one day after the surgery and were doing well afterward. We have evaluated your prognosis and will instruct you on follow-up requirements.
Patient:Patient Thank you, doctor. What should I do next?
Doctor:Doctor We will give you instructions on postoperative care and schedule follow-up appointments to monitor your condition.

Patient:Patient I was diagnosed with spinal muscular atrophy when I was one year old through muscle biopsy. I have never walked and I am unable to move my arms or legs. I have been completely bedridden since I suffered aspiration pneumonia when I was eight.
Doctor:Doctor I understand. And do you use continuous positive airway pressure during sleep?
Doctor:Doctor Alright. Can you tell me about your neck?
Patient:Patient I usually have my neck turned to the left because I have difficulty breathing and sometimes experience dyspnea when I turn my neck to the right.

Patient:Patient Yes, I underwent two rounds of general anesthesia for scoliosis surgery in 2008 and 2010. And I had a history of tracheostomy for dyspnea that occurred in the ICU after undergoing general anesthesia for the second time.

Patient:Patient Yes, I can. And I am able to eat regular food.

Patient:Patient I have been complaining of pain in my TMJ and temporal area during mouth opening for 10 years, which has hindered me from receiving treatment for long-term molar pain.

Doctor:Doctor Alright. But we decided to defer general anesthesia due to a high risk of respiratory complications based on your medical history and physical examination, and instead performed local anesthesia of your TMJ area.

Doctor:Doctor We determined that you had severe pain in the bilateral temporal and TMJ area due to hyperextension of the mouth closing muscle while opening your mouth, and performed local anesthesia to alleviate tension in the TMJ and mouth closing muscle area during dental treatment.
Doctor:Doctor At the dental clinic, 1 mL 0.5% levobupivacaine was injected on each side of the TMJ and temporalis fascia before performing oral and maxillofacial surgery.
